The Imperial House of Japan, pp. 64-65. His reign started in 850 and ended in 858.Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, p. 112; Brown, Delmer M. (1979). Gukanshō, pp. 264-265; Varley, H. Paul. (1980). Jinnō Shōtōki, p. 165. ==Traditional narrative== Before he became the monarch, this prince's personal name (imina)Brown, pp. 264; before to Emperor Jomei, the personal names of the emperors were very long and people did not generally use them; however, the number of characters in each name were shorter after Jomei's reign. was .Titsingh, p. 112; Brown p. 285. He was also known as Tamura-no-mikadoVarley, p. 165. or Tamura-tei.Ponsonby-Fane, p. 8. He was the eldest son of Emperor Ninmyō. Montoku had six Imperial consorts and 29 Imperial sons.Brown, p. 285. ===Events of Montoku's life=== Before he became the monarch, he was Crown Prince for 8 years. * 6 May 850 (Kashō 3, 21st day of the 3rd month): In the 17th year of Ninmyō-tennō 's reign (仁明天皇17年), the emperor died. His eldest son received the succession (senso).Titsingh, p. 112; Brown, p. 284. * 850 (Kashō 3, 4th month): Emperor Montoku formally acceded to the throne (sokui). This was confirmed in ceremonies.Varley, p. 44; a distinct act of senso is unrecognized prior to Emperor Tenji; and all sovereigns except Jitō, Yōzei, Go-Toba, and Fushimi have senso and sokui in the same year until the reign of Emperor Go-Murakami. Compare Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), Ceremony of Accession (Sokui-no-Rei); retrieved 2011-12-23. * 850 (Kashō 3, 5th month): The widow of Emperor Saga, who was the mother of Emperor Ninmyō and the grandmother of Emperor Montoku, died.Titsingh, p. 112. * 850 (Kashō 3, 11th month): The emperor named Korehito-shinnō, the 4th son of Emperor Montoku as his heir.Brown, p. 286. This 9-month-old baby was also the grandson of Fujiwara no Yoshifusa who was Minister of the Right (udaijin).Titsingh, p. 113. * 855 (Saikō 2, 1st month): The Emishi organized a rebellion. In response, a force of 1,000 men and provisions were sent to the north.Titsingh, p. 114. * 855 (Saikō 2, 5th month): The head of the great statute of Buddha in the Tōdai-ji fell off. * 7 October 858 (Ten'an 2, 27th day of the 8th month): Montoku died at the age of 32.Brown, p. 285-286; Varley, p. 165. ===After his death=== According to the Imperial Household Agency, the mausoleum (misasagi) of Montoku is in Kyoto. The emperor is traditionally venerated at a memorial Shinto shrine at this location. The site is formally named Tamura no misasagi.Ponsonby-Fane, p. 420. ==Eras of reign== The years of Montoku's reign are identified by more than one era name or nengō. * Kashō (848-851) * Ninju (851-854) * Saikō (854-857) * Ten'an (857-859) ==Related pages== * Emperor of Japan * List of emperors of Japan * Japanese imperial family tree ==References== == Other websites == Category:Emperors of Japan Category:827 births Category:858 deaths
